p: To assess trypanocidal activity as described by [ 16], a fixed concentration of 25 µg/mL of crude extracts was mixed with cultures of Trypanosoma brucei in a 96-well plate, and the mixtures were incubated for 48 h. After incubation, the parasites that survived the treatment with the tested samples were enumerated by the addition of a resazurin-based reagent. Cells were considered viable when they were capable of reducing resazurin to resorufin (a fluorophore with Exc 560/Em 590). Results were expressed as percentage parasite viability of the resorufin fluorescence in compound-treated wells relative to untreated controls (pentamidine), determined by a Spectramax M3 microplate reader (Molecular Devices, CA, USA). Compounds were tested in duplicate, and standard deviations (SD) were evaluated. Extracts that reduced parasite viability to <20% were considered for further testing (dose–response cytotoxicity assays). Pentamidine is a common drug used for the treatment of trypanosomiasis.
